0.text: Johnnie, a determined 19 year old girl, works at the cotton mill to support her family. She plans to pay back all the debts they have accumulated.

errors.span: the spinning department of the mill,

1.text: Johnnie is attracted to her boss, Gray Stoddard, a passionate socialist who believes marriage should be based on the potential of the children. Johnnie is promoted to supervisor in the spinning department of the mill, but begins to understand the negative aspects of working in a factory.

2.text: Shade, a fellow worker, becomes intrigued by Johnnie and confesses his feelings for her. He wants to marry her, but she refuses because she has to care for her mother and siblings. Shade knows that Johnnie's invention is patentable and he needs to control her in order to profit from it.

errors.span: Miss Sessions holds a dance for the members of her Uplift Club.

3.text: Miss Sessions holds a dance for the members of her Uplift Club.

errors.span: Charlie is surprised to learn that Johnnie is a mill girl.

errors.span: Johnnie struggles to support her family and the children working in the mills

6.text: Johnnie struggles to support her family and the children working in the mills. She pays Pap to let Deanie stay home from work, but he sends Pony to work in her place.

7.text: Stoddard, a rich man, visits Pap to ask about Johnnie's device. Pap tells him to leave Johnnie alone as she is not interested in him. Stoddard surprises Himes by saying he would be willing to marry Johnnie.

9.text: Himes explains to Shade that if Stoddard marries Johnnie, he will likely end up in prison. Shade agrees to talk to Stoddard to explain that Johnnie is his promised wife.

10.text: Johnnie searches for Stoddard, who has gone missing. Uncle Pros explains that six months ago, he was walking to deliver silver ore to Johnnie when Rudd Dawson stopped him and insisted he go talk to Will Venters, Jess Groner, and his brother Sam. Sam claimed that Shade Buckheath was going to help kidnap one of the mill owners for ransom.

errors.span: cabin where he's been held captive for over a month

11.text: Johnnie and Pros rescue Stoddard from a cabin where he's been held captive for over a month. As they speed away in Stoddard's car, they're chased by men with guns. Stoddard is grazed by a bullet, but they manage to escape.

12.text: Gray waits for Johnnie at her home and tells her he doesn't care what other people think and that she's beautiful. They embrace and kiss.

0.text: George Babbitt is a successful real estate agent in Zenith, a city full of factories and skyscrapers. He lives in a nice neighborhood with his wife Myra and their three children.

errors.span: dissatisfied they feel with their lives

1.text: At work, Babbitt dictates a letter to a client and writes an advertisement for a burial place. He then meets with Paul Riesling, a younger brother of sorts, at the Zenith Athletic Club. They discuss their wives and how dissatisfied they feel with their lives.

2.text: Meanwhile, union officials are planning to get Babbitt to help them get rid of Seneca Doane, a radical lawyer who is a threat to them.

errors.span: For two weeks, the Babbitts prepare for a dinner party, marveling at the caliber of guests they will host.

4.text: The guests arrive and enjoy cocktails and dinner. The conversation ranges from the pros and cons of small town life versus city life to spiritualism.

errors.span: Babbitt and Paul go on a trip to Maine without their families.

0.text: Esther is raised by her godmother until she passes away. Mr. Jarndyce, a humane and singular man, offers to place Esther at a first-rate establishment where she'll be provided for and educated.

40.text: One night, Esther sits in the porch and thinks about her old looks. Allan comes home and asks her what she is thinking about. She tells him that she is thinking about how she and her husband are not rich in the bank, but they have always prospered and have enough.

0.text: Jurgis, a hardworking man, falls in love with Ona after meeting her at a horse fair. He decides to go to America and marry her, believing it will make him rich.

errors.span: Upon arriving in Chicago, the group of 12 immigrants are tricked by an agent who charges them a lot of money

1.text: Upon arriving in Chicago, the group of 12 immigrants are tricked by an agent who charges them a lot of money. Jurgis gets a job at Brown's, and the family begins to pool their resources to afford a house.

2.text: The family's home is infested with vermin, and the children become weaker and more prone to illness. The harsh winter makes things worse, and the factory shuts down, leaving many workers unemployed.

errors.span: Meanwhile, Tamoszius Kuszleika, a musician, becomes fascinated with Marija and eventually asks her to marry him.

5.text: Marija loses her job at the canning factory after being a troublemaker in the union. She gets a new job as a "beef-trimmer" but works long hours in poor conditions.

errors.span: Ona gives birth to a healthy baby boy, Antanas.

6.text: Ona gives birth to a healthy baby boy, Antanas. However, Jurgis is injured at work and confined to bed for months, and his family struggles to make ends meet.

7.text: Ona tells Jurgis that Connor, the boss, forced her to come to his house at night and threatened to ruin them all if she didn't comply. Jurgis attacks Connor, and is sentenced to 30 days in jail.

8.text: When he is released, he finds that the house has been repaired and new curtains have been installed. He wonders who did the work and how they could afford it.

antecedants: Ona gives birth to a healthy baby boy

errors.span: Ona dies during childbirth, leaving Jurgis devastated.

9.text: Ona dies during childbirth, leaving Jurgis devastated. He spends all of the family's money on alcohol and is unable to find work.

errors.span: He enjoys his new life, but often feels miserable due to his conscience.

10.text: Jurgis becomes a tramp and travels from place to place, working odd jobs to earn money. He enjoys his new life, but often feels miserable due to his conscience.

11.text: One day, Jurgis gets a job working for a company that is tunneling beneath the city to lay telephone wires. He is happy to have a job that will last the entire winter. However, he soon realizes he has no place to go during the evenings and no one to talk to.

12.text: Jurgis meets Jack Duane, who tells him he can show him how to earn a living in the criminal underworld of Chicago. They wait in the shadows and attack random men, robbing them of their belongings.

errors.span: Jurgis becomes a Republican and works to promote Scotty Doyle
the packers refuse to pay the union's demands,

13.text: Jurgis becomes a Republican and works to promote Scotty Doyle, the Republican nominee for alderman. After the elections, the packers refuse to pay the union's demands, and the unions decide to go on strike.

14.text: The packers hire thousands of black workers from the South to replace the striking workers, and violence erupts in the yards as the black workers are treated as slaves.

errors.span: Jurgis becomes involved with a woman

15.text: Jurgis becomes involved with a woman and attacks Connor, the boss who seduced his wife. He is arrested and his bail is reduced to $300, crippling him financially.

16.text: Jurgis attends a political meeting and is captivated by a passionate speaker who explains the principles of Socialism. He meets many other socialists who speak at meetings and write articles for the socialist press.

errors.span: The party at the hotel celebrates the election results

17.text: The party at the hotel celebrates the election results. The vote in Packingtown has increased from 500 to over 6,300 in one year. The orator urges the crowd to organize and find the men who voted for them.

errors.span: John Marcher had always felt that he had a special connection with May Bartram, but when she was dying, he felt that their intimacy had failed him

8.text: John Marcher had always felt that he had a special connection with May Bartram, but when she was dying, he felt that their intimacy had failed him. He went to her grave and stayed away for a year. During that time, he felt that the garden of death gave him the few square feet of earth on which he could still live. It was as if, being nothing anywhere else for anyone, he were just everything here. He settled to live, feeding all on the sense that he once had lived, and dependent on it not alone for a support but for an identity.

errors.span: The touch in the event was the face of a fellow-mortal
The most extraordinary thing that had happened to him was the sight that named to him something he had utterly missed

9.text: The touch in the event was the face of a fellow-mortal. This face looked into Marcher's own, at the cemetery, with an expression like the cut of a blade. He felt it so deep down that he winced at the steady thrust. The person who so mutely assaulted him was a figure he had noticed, absorbed by a grave a short distance away. Marcher was conscious of the fact that the image of scarred passion presented to him was conscious too. The most extraordinary thing that had happened to him was the sight that named to him something he had utterly missed. He gazed, drew breath, in pain.

0.text: Alice falls down a well and lands in a hall with doors all around. She opens a small door to a beautiful garden using a golden key she finds on a table. She decides to drink from a bottle labeled "Drink Me" in hopes it will make her small enough to fit through the door. It works, and she grows to over 9 feet tall. She realizes she's forgotten the key to the garden door, so she asks the white rabbit for help, but he runs away.

0.text: Socrates is cited to appear before the court, and Hermogenes, one of his close acquaintances, asks him why he isn't preparing his defense. Socrates says he has spent his whole life preparing his defense, by living a life free of wrongdoing. Hermogenes points out that Athenian juries often put innocent people to death, but Socrates says the divinity prevents him from preparing his defense. He says he has lived a life of holiness and justice.

1.text: Socrates says that his friends and acquaintances have a positive opinion of him, and that if he lives longer, he will grow old and his senses will weaken. He says that perhaps God is intervening in his behalf to allow him to die in old age, which is considered the easiest and most peaceful way to die. He says that if he had prepared a defense, he would have ended his life in a less pleasant way.

2.text: Socrates says he will not display any zeal to prolong his life, and would rather die than beg the court for mercy.

errors.span: Socrates says he is at a loss to understand why they think that, since he has been seen sacrificing at common festivals

3.text: When the prosecution accuses him of not recognizing the gods recognized by the state, and introducing novel divinities, Socrates says he is at a loss to understand why they think that, since he has been seen sacrificing at common festivals. He says he only speaks of a divinity, and that he is not lying about it, as he has never been shown to be a deceiver.

antecedants: some disbelieving him

4.text: The judges murmur their dissent at Socrates' words, some disbelieving him out of envy and others out of disbelief. Socrates says that Apollo once declared him to be the most virtuous man in the world, and that Lycurgus, the great lawgiver of Lacedaemon, was also declared to be virtuous by the gods. He asks the judges to investigate his claims, and asks if there is anyone else who is less enslaved by the appetites of the body, or more independent, or more just than he is.

antecedants: Socrates says

5.text: Socrates says that he has always sought to learn every good thing he could, and that his fellow citizens and strangers alike choose to spend time with him. He asks the judges to consider how many people owe him gratitude, and how no one has ever tried to collect money from him. He asks if anyone has ever changed from being religious to irreligious under his influence, or become a drunkard or a glutton.

6.text: Meletus says that Socrates has persuaded others to disobey their parents. Socrates says that people often prefer to follow experts in various fields, such as education and health, rather than their parents. He says that in matters of military affairs, people choose their generals over their own family members. He asks why he should be prosecuted for being an expert in education.

7.text: Socrates believes that the time has come for him to die.

8.text: When the case is decided against him, Socrates neither suggests a counter-penalty nor allows his friends to do so on his behalf. He also refuses to be smuggled out of prison.

9.text: When the trial ends, Socrates says that those who instructed the witnesses to lie and bear false witness against him must be conscious of their own impiety and injustice. He says that he has not committed any of the crimes for which death is the penalty, such as robbing temples or selling freemen into slavery. He asks why he should lower his head for being innocent.

antecedants: Socrates says that

10.text: Socrates says that he finds consolation in the example of Palamedes, who also met a similar fate. He says that he has never wronged anyone, and has always tried to benefit those who have spent time with him.

11.text: Apollodorus, an enthusiastic follower of Socrates, innocently exclaims that it is hardest to see Socrates unjustly put to death. Socrates gently strokes Apollodorus' head and asks if he would have preferred to see him die for a just reason.

12.text: Socrates also says that he saw Anytus pass by, and remarked that he thought he had performed a great deed by putting Socrates to death. Socrates says that whichever of them has achieved the best and noblest thing for all future time is the real victor in the suit.

antecedants: Socrates says that he

13.text: Socrates says that he once associated with Anytus' son, and that he seemed to have strength of soul. He says that the son is likely to be led into depravity without a guardian to guide him.

errors.span: his reputation still lives on, due to his son's poor upbringing and his own lack of human feeling

14.text: The prophecy about the son of Anytus came true, as the young man fell into a life of drinking and became worthless. As for Anytus himself, his reputation still lives on, due to his son's poor upbringing and his own lack of human feeling.

15.text: Socrates drew the jealousy of the court, but still managed to die in the easiest way possible. He displayed no weakness in the face of death, and welcomed death's embrace.

16.text: Apollodorus praises Socrates for his wisdom and nobility.

errors.span: The Epicureans have always answered that it is not they, but their accusers who represent human nature in a degrading light

0.text: There are few circumstances among those which make up the present condition of human knowledge more unlike what might have been expected or more significant of the backward state in which speculation on the most important subjects still lingers. From the dawn of philosophy, the question of the summum bonum or what is the same thing, concerning the foundation of morality has been accounted the main problem in speculative thought. The difficulty is not avoided by having recourse to the popular theory of a natural faculty informing us of right and wrong. The Epicureans have always answered that it is not they, but their accusers who represent human nature in a degrading light. Utilitarianism could only attain its end by the general cultivation of nobleness of character, even if each individual is only benefited by the nobleness of others.

1.text: Though it is only in a very imperfect state of the world's arrangements that one can best serve the happiness of others by sacrificing his own, so long as the world is in that imperfect state, I fully acknowledge that the readiness to make such sacrifice is the highest virtue. In this condition of the world, the conscious ability to do without happiness gives the best prospect of realizing happiness as is attainable. Utilitarianism requires one to be as strictly impartial as a disinterested and benevolent spectator. Utilitarians are aware that there are other desirable possessions and qualities besides virtue. Personal desires and partialities are always involved in moral conflicts. The ultimate sanction of all morality is subjective feeling in our own minds.

2.text: Will not exist in the mind unless it is believed to have its root out of the mind; and that if a person is able to say to himself that which is restraining him is only a feeling in his own mind, he may possibly draw the conclusion that when the feeling ceases the obligation ceases. But is this danger confined to the utilitarian morality? Does the belief that moral obligation has its seat outside the mind make the feeling of it too strong to be got rid of? The fact is otherwise, that all moralists admit and lament the ease with which conscience can be silenced or stifled. Society between human beings can only exist on the understanding that the interests of all are to be consulted. Virtue, according to the utilitarian doctrine, is not originally part of the end, but it is capable of becoming so.

errors.span: To find the common attributes of a variety of objects, it is necessary to begin by surveying the modes of action and arrangements of human affairs which are classed as just or unjust.

3.text: To find the common attributes of a variety of objects, it is necessary to begin by surveying the modes of action and arrangements of human affairs which are classed as just or unjust. The things well known to excite the sentiments associated with those names are of a very multifarious character. In the first place, it is considered unjust to deprive any one of his personal liberty, property, or any other thing which belongs to him by law. But this judgment admits of exceptions arising from the other forms in which the notions of justice and injustice present themselves. Some maintain that no law, however bad, ought to be disobeyed by an individual. The superior intelligence and sympathy of man enables him to attach himself to the collective idea of his tribe, country, or mankind in such a manner that any act hurtful to them rouses his instinct of sympathy and urges him to resistance.

4.text: Again, when the legitimacy of inflicting punishment is admitted, how many conflicting conceptions of justice come to light in discussing the proper apportionment of punishment to offences. No rule on this subject recommends itself so strongly to the primitive and spontaneous sentiment of justice as the lex talionis, an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth. Though this principle of the Jewish and of the Mahomedan law has been generally abandoned in Europe, there is, I suspect, in most minds, a secret hankering after it. Justice is a name for certain classes of moral rules which concern the essentials of human well-being more nearly than any other rules for the guidance of life.

One day, Mary, a young girl living nearby, finds him lying on his bed hysterical and unable to speak. Dr. Craven determines that Colin is suffering from a severe case of hysteria. Colin begins to recover and Mary spends time with him, feeding him and talking to him. Colin makes himself believe he will get well, which is half the battle. 0.text: Among the memories of Socrates, none is more deserving of record than the counsel he took with himself regarding his defense and ending his life. Others have written on this theme, but none have brought out clearly the fact that Socrates had come to regard death as preferable to life. Hermogenes, one of Socrates' close friends, tells us that seeing Socrates discoursing on every topic rather than his impending trial, he put it to him whether he ought not to be debating the line of his defense. Socrates replied that twice already he had essayed to consider his defense and twice the divinity hindered him.

1.text: Socrates' friends and intimates have formed an opinion about him, and he knows that he cannot escape paying the penalty of old age in increasing dimness of sight and dulness of hearing. He adds that if he is sentenced to death, it is plain he will be allowed to die the easiest way, and one that will cause the least trouble to his friends. For him, death is the only way to end his days wasted by disease or old age, on which a confluent stream of evil things converges.

2.text: Socrates says he will display no zeal to bring about his death, and if by proclaiming all the blessings he end up wearying the court, he will choose death rather than supplicate in servile sort for leave to live longer. Hermogenes states that when the prosecution accused him of not recognizing the gods recognized by the state, Socrates stepped forward and said: "In the first place, sirs, I am at a loss to imagine on what ground Meletus asserts that I do not recognize the gods which are recognized by the state." 3.text: As they listened to these words, the judges murmured their dissent, some as disbelieving what was said, and others out of envy that Socrates should actually receive from heaven more than they themselves. Socrates returned to the charge and said: "Come, lend me your ears while I tell you something more, so that those of you who choose may go to a still greater length in refusing to believe that I am thus highly honored by the divine powers." He adds that as Lycurgus entered the temple, the god addressed him with the words: "I am considering whether to call thee god or man."

4.text: Socrates says that he has always inquired into and learned every good thing in his power, and that he labored not in vain, what more conclusive evidence than the fact that so many of his fellow citizens choose his society in preference to that of others. He adds that though all know well enough that he is wholly unable to repay them in money, so many are eager to present him with some gift. During the siege, while others were pitying themselves, he lived in no greater straits than when the city was at the height of her prosperity.

5.text: Meletus exclaims that he knows those whom Socrates persuaded to obey himself rather than the fathers who begat them. Socrates admits that in the case of education, he has made the matter a study, and with regard to health, a man prefers to obey his doctor rather than his parents. He adds that in choosing generals, citizens set their fathers and brothers aside, by comparison with those whom they believe to be the wisest authorities on military matters. Shade Buckheath, a young man from Cottonville, has always been fascinated by the prospect of finding a silver mine. One day, Gray hires Johnnie as a waitress. 0.text: In writing this account, the narrator divulges the great secret of his life - the secret he has guarded for years. He was born in a small town of Georgia after the Civil War. His mother decided to enter him in the public school and he made one friend. As the time for his graduation grew near, his mother told him his father wanted him to go to Harvard or Yale. After arriving in Atlanta, he hires a wagon to take his trunk to his lodging place. He sees colored people in large numbers and asks his companion if all the colored people in Atlanta lived in this street. He sits down with the porter and is not hungry. The porter tells him he is adopting him into his large family. He spends the afternoon looking around the town. The next day he starts work at a cigar factory.

1.text: After spending several weeks in sight-seeing, the narrator decides to return to the United States and live among the people. His millionaire offers him a check for five hundred dollars and wishes him good luck. He spends most of his time with the doctor among his friends and acquaintances. The social life among colored people is more developed in Washington than in any other city in the country. The United States puts a greater premium on color than anything else in the world. A young man returns to his hometown to find his old music teacher. He is immediately attracted to the girl who sings at the church. He decides to pursue her romantically, but is afraid to speak his feelings for fear of losing her.

0.text: Gargantua, the son of Grangousier, is a young man of great talent and intelligence. He is especially close to his governess, Jobelin, who has taught him many things. Gargantua enjoys spending time with his father and enjoys writing poetry and playing music. After Gargantua spends his time playing, drinking, and sleeping, Ponocrates resolves to bring him up in another kind. For a while he bears with Gargantua, considering that nature cannot endure a sudden change. Gargantua and his men embark on a dangerous adventure to find out what to do about the upcoming battle.

1.text: Gargantua and his men make an excursion into the country till they come near to the Vauguyon, the valley of Guyon. They return and take opportunity to pass above the hospital to try what intelligence they can get. In a pastoral lodge, they carry manacled as spies. Gargantua and his men defeat the army of Picrochole. It is ordained that into this religious order should be admitted no women that are not fair, well-featured, and of a sweet disposition. The ladies of the religious order of Theleme are apparelled after their own pleasure and liking. Pantagruel, a philosopher and thief, meets a lion who cleanses his wound.

Panurge falls in love with a lady of Paris and tries to convince her to marry him. She refuses, saying she is not interested in him. Panurge sets fire to the train and they all burn up. Pantagruel makes a prisoner believe they have an army at sea. Pantagruel decides to conquer the kingdom of Dipsodes. He gathers a group of men and prepares to attack the city. Panurge marries the daughter of the king of India and fights against the devil.

3.text: Panurge finds much good in the counsel of women, chiefly in that of the old wives. He tells Pantagruel that his virtue and worth will never be known until he gets a wife and makes a full half of a married couple. Panurge says that his wife will be with child, but not of him. Panurge and Pantagruel return to Pantagruel's court, partly pleased and other part discontented. Friar John counsels Panurge to take good heed that he solder well together the joints of the double-backed and two-bellied beast and fortify his nerves so strongly that there be no discontinuance in the knocks of the venerean.

4.text: Pantagruel is present at the trial of Judge Bridlegoose, who decides causes and controversies in law by the chance and fortune of the dice. On the day following, the presidents, senators, and counsellors pray him to enter in with them to hear the decision of all the causes, arguments, and reasons Bridlegoose would produce why he pronounced a certain sentence against Toucheronde. Trinquamelle asks Bridlegoose why he does not livre up these fair throws and chances the same day and hour. Panurge tells Pantagruel that Triboulet hints that his wife will be a drunkard. They decide to send Triboulet back to Blois and seek the advice of the king. Pantagruel sails with his fleet to the island of Medamothy, where he purchases exotic animals.

He sends Malicorne to give him a true account of his health at the beginning of his voyage. Panurge tells that if they touch at the great kingdom of Gebarim, they would be honorably received and treated by the sovereign of that country, King Ohabe. Friar John relates how Basche, a brave, honest, noble-spirited gentleman, was every day cited, warned, and prosecuted at the suit and for the sport and fancy of the fat prior of St. Louant. Pantagruel shoots the physeter with darts and it dies. He demands a parley with the queen, who offers to hold of him and his the whole island and country to obey him in all his commands.

The devil fails to take any of the corn and the farmer makes good money of his radishes. Pantagruel gives to the poor box of the fabric of the church 18,000 royals in commiseration of the poverty of the people and the calamity of the place. After dinner, they take leave of the right reverend Homenas and promise them that at their coming to Rome, they would make their applications so effectually to the pope that he would speedily be sure to visit them in person. Pantagruel feels a pressing retraction in his soul, which like a voice admonishes him not to land there.

After supper, the queen makes them choose one of the most illustrious lanterns to guide them. Bacbuc directs her attendants to make them drink.

0.text: The author attempts to explain and defend the Utilitarian or Happiness theory. He begins by explaining the theory itself, stating that actions are right insofar as they promote happiness and wrong insofar as they produce the opposite of happiness. He then explains that happiness is not a continuous state of highly pleasurable excitement, but rather a life of many pleasures and few pains with a predominance of active over passive pleasures. He also explains that happiness is not unattainable, and that those who are denied the liberty to use the sources of happiness within their reach will not fail to find happiness if they escape the great sources of physical and mental suffering.

1.text: The author explains that the highest virtue is the readiness to make the ultimate sacrifice for others. He explains that utilitarianism recognizes the power of self-sacrifice in humans, but does not require it. He explains that utilitarianism does not require people to focus on the good of society as a whole, but rather on the good of individuals.

2.text: He explains that utilitarianism is often criticized for being immoral, but that this is due to confusion between expediency and utility. He explains that utilitarianism provides a standard by which conflicts can be resolved.

antecedants: explains that

3.text: He explains that utilitarianism either has or does not have all the sanctions that belong to any other moral system. He explains that the ultimate sanction of all morality is a subjective feeling in our own minds, and that there is no reason why it cannot attach itself to utilitarianism.

antecedants: The author explains that

4.text: The author explains that moral obligation does not need to have its source outside the mind, and that moral feelings can attach themselves to the pleasures and pains of others. He explains that social feelings are a natural sentiment for humans, and that as society grows, people grow up naturally inclined to pay regard to the interests of others.

errors.span: He explains that happiness is desirable as an end

antecedants: He explains that

5.text: He explains that happiness is desirable as an end, and that virtue is one of the parts that make up happiness. He explains that the will can be cultivated through the association of doing right with pleasure and doing wrong with pain.

antecedants: He explains that

6.text: He explains that there is no necessary connection between the question of the origin of justice and its binding force. He explains that to determine whether the reality to which the feeling of justice corresponds is one that needs a special revelation, it is necessary to determine what is the distinguishing character of justice.

7.text: There are many different opinions on what constitutes justice. Some believe that those who need the most should receive the most, others believe those who work harder should receive more, and still others believe those who produce more should receive more.

8.text: The author believes that the sentiment of justice is composed of two elements: a rational and an animal element. The rational element is the obligation to provide for the security of one's existence. The animal element is the thirst for retaliation.

antecedants: The author believes that

9.text: The author believes that the idea of justice presupposes two things: a rule of conduct and a sentiment that sanctions the rule. The first must be common to all mankind, and intended for the good of all. The other (the sentiment) is a desire that punishment be suffered by those who infringe the rule.

10.text: The author believes that the feeling of justice is so powerful that it becomes a moral necessity, analogous to physical necessity.

errors.span: If the author's analysis of the

11.text: If the author's analysis of the

12.text: When discussing the proper apportionment of punishment to offenses, many conflicting conceptions of justice arise. Some believe that everyone should be paid equally regardless of skill level, while others believe that society owes a larger return to those who are more efficient and whose work is more useful.

antecedants: The author believes that

13.text: The author believes that justice is a name for certain moral rules that concern the essentials of human well-being more than any other rules for the guidance of life. The most marked cases of injustice are acts of wrongful aggression or withholding from someone what is rightfully theirs.

14.text: The considerations presented resolve the only real difficulty in the utilitarian theory of morals. Justice remains the appropriate name for certain social utilities that are more important than any others.

0.text: Mr. Phileas Fogg lives in a house in Saville Row, Burlington Gardens, where Sheridan died in 1814. He is a member of the Reform Club, an exclusive club that he seems to avoid attracting attention. He has no public employment and lives alone in his house.

1.text: Phileas Fogg bets 20,000 pounds against anyone who wishes that he will make the tour of the world in 80 days or less. The news of the bet spreads through the Reform Club and the newspapers, and people think him a lunatic.

errors.span: Phileas Fogg and his servant, Passepartout, are arrested for the murder of a young widow.
the murder of a young widow

2.text: Phileas Fogg and his servant, Passepartout, are arrested for the murder of a young widow. Fix, an agent of the Reform Club, suspects that Fogg has a motive for securing his innocent complicity.

errors.span: Phileas Fogg and Aouda descend into the cabin at midnight

3.text: Phileas Fogg and Aouda descend into the cabin at midnight, having been preceded by Fix, who lies down on one of the cots. The next morning, they reach the coast and John Bunsby asserts that they will reach Shanghai in time.

errors.span: Passepartout follows the clown and soon finds himself in the Japanese quarter.

4.text: Passepartout follows the clown and soon finds himself in the Japanese quarter. He is engaged to act in the Japanese troupe.

errors.span: Phileas Fogg, a wealthy businessman, travels by train to New York to meet with his business partner.

5.text: Phileas Fogg, a wealthy businessman, travels by train to New York to meet with his business partner. During the trip, he is attacked by a band of Sioux Indians and his servant, Fix, is captured. Phileas Fogg announces that he has accomplished the journey around the world in 80 days.

0.text: John meets May at a party and is immediately drawn to her. They realize they've met before years ago in Naples. They spend the rest of the party reminiscing about their past encounter.

errors.span: As time passes, they find themselves
John takes May on outings in London, visiting museums and other attractions

1.text: As time passes, they find themselves spending more and more time together due to the death of May's great aunt, who had been her primary caretaker. John takes May on outings in London, visiting museums and other attractions.

errors.span: John never intended for anyone to know about his secret
since his mouth was forced open early on
be careful not to let it lapse

2.text: John never intended for anyone to know about his secret, but since his mouth was forced open early on, he's decided to make the most of it. He values his character enough to be careful not to let it lapse. He's careful not to bring up his obsession with May, as he feels it's best to keep the topic light and familiar. May begins to observe John's life in the light of what she knows about him.

errors.span: May and John have been friends for a long time.
antecedants: John meets May at a party

errors.span: May and John have been friends for a long time.
John is afraid of something but doesn't know what.
May eventually confesses to John that she fears she has a disorder in her blood.
see what she's been waiting to see
He doesn't directly ask May what she knows, but instead asks her what she thinks the worst thing that could happen to him could be
lost her power to conceive such things

3.text: May and John have been friends for a long time. May knows John's secret and helps him pass as a normal man. John is afraid of something but doesn't know what. May eventually confesses to John that she fears she has a disorder in her blood. John worries that she might die before she has the chance to see what she's been waiting to see. As May's condition grows more serious, John becomes increasingly aware of his own age. He wonders if he will be associated with any sort of awful crash or ignominy as he ages. One afternoon, John visits May and notices she appears much older than before. He feels strangely abandoned by her. He doesn't directly ask May what she knows, but instead asks her what she thinks the worst thing that could happen to him could be. May asks why he assumes she hasn't lost her power to conceive such things.

errors.span: the thing they've been waiting for

4.text: May finally reveals to John that she knows something that she has never told him. She explains that the thing they've been waiting for has finally come to fruition, and that it has marked John in some way.

5.text: May eventually passes away, and John feels as though he has been deprived of something that he should have had, given the intimacy that he shared with her.

errors.span: He returns to May's grave on a monthly basis

6.text: John travels to the depths of Asia in order to distract himself from his loss. He returns to May's grave on a monthly basis, and begins to feel as though it's the only place where he can truly live.

7.text: However, an incident occurs that changes John's life forever. He is struck by a sudden realization that his ache has only been drugged, and that it has been throbbing beneath the surface for some time.

errors.span: to bleed so much and still live

8.text: John notices a middle-aged man standing before a fresh grave, who appears to be deeply affected by the grave. John is struck by the man's grief and wonders what could have caused him to bleed so much and still live.

9.text: John realizes that he has never experienced any sort of passion in his life, and that he has simply survived and maundered. He realizes that the woman he has been mourning all these years was actually what he had been missing in his life.

antecedants: his obsession with May

errors.span: He turns to the tombstone in order to avoid the Beast that he sees approaching

10.text: He realizes that he had been foolish to not love her, and that if he had, he would have lived. He turns to the tombstone in order to avoid the Beast that he sees approaching.

6.text: Pantagruel debates with the masters of the colleges and universities, and is eventually asked to help solve a legal dispute between two lords. He pronounces his verdict, saying that the defendant should reimburse the plaintiff for the cost of the wild pistachios and bladder-nuts. Both parties are satisfied with the verdict.

errors.span: Thaumast, a scholar from England, travels to France to meet Pantagruel and discuss philosophical concepts.

Panurge decides to marry and have children to perpetuate his name and inheritance. Pantagruel instructs Panurge to sleep without eating in order to receive the gift of divination.

11.text: Panurge consults several fortune tellers about his marriage, and each predicts that his wife will make him a cuckold and steal his goods. Panurge is troubled by these predictions, but Friar John convinces him to marry as soon as possible because the end of the world is approaching.

errors.span: They are taken before Gripe-men-all, a dreadful monster who asks them a riddle

28.text: The group visits Queen Entelechy, who is convinced they are men of great knowledge and virtue. She shows them around her palace, where her officers perform strange experiments.

29.text: The group sails to the island of Frieze, where they see many different creatures. They then arrive at the palace of Lantern-land, where the Queen of Lantern-land receives them with hospitality.

30.text: They follow the great lantern down the steps and reach a portal with the inscription "In wine, truth". The priestess Bacbuc and her attendants take them to the middle of the temple, where there is a fountain made of alabaster.

31.text: Bacbuc asks Panurge who among them would like to have the word of the Bottle. Panurge volunteers, and Bacbuc dresses him in a special attire and leads him to a chapel where the sacred Bottle is kept. Panurge hears the word Trinc, which means drink. Bacbuc explains that by drinking wine, humans become divine.

0.text: Tess Durbeyfield learns that her family is the last remaining noble family in the county, which could bring other nobles to their area. Her mother believes this could lead to a marriage with a nobleman for Tess.

1.text: Tess agrees to work for Alec d'Urberville, the son of the family, to improve her family's status. She develops feelings for Alec, but eventually realizes she never truly loved him.

errors.span: Tess's baby falls ill and dies

2.text: Tess's baby falls ill and dies. She performs a burial service for the baby herself.

3.text: Tess becomes determined to leave her past behind her and becomes a dairy maid. She is excited to be able to be close to the former estates of the d'Urbervilles, as she feels it will allow her to reflect on the fact that the family has fallen.

errors.span: Angel Clare, a poor parson's son, decides not to enter the church and instead chooses to study various activities

4.text: Angel Clare, a poor parson's son, decides not to enter the church and instead chooses to study various activities. He moves to Talbothays Dairy to learn the trade of farming. He becomes close friends with the dairyman and his family, and spends most of his time reading and playing his harp.

errors.span: Tess and Angel grow closer to each other, but have not yet reached the point of falling in love. Angel eventually confesses that he loves her dearly

5.text: Angel notices Tess, a young milkmaid who seems to have a touch of rarity about her. As the season matures, Tess and Angel grow closer to each other, but have not yet reached the point of falling in love. Angel eventually confesses that he loves her dearly.

6.text: Angel asks Tess to marry him, but she initially refuses, saying she doesn't want to get married at all. Angel explains his parents are very simple-mannered Evangelicals and wouldn't object to her. Tess eventually agrees to marry Angel if it's for his happiness and convenience.

7.text: Angel and Tess go on a romantic trip before the wedding, and Tess worries something might happen to ruin her happiness. She slips a note under Angel's door about her past, but he doesn't seem to have received it.

errors.span: None of Tess's friends are able to attend the wedding, as they live too far away.
Angel's family also does not attend, as they disapprove of his choice of bride
antecedants: Angel explains his parents are very simple-mannered Evangelicals and wouldn't object to her

8.text: None of Tess's friends are able to attend the wedding, as they live too far away. Angel's family also does not attend, as they disapprove of his choice of bride.

errors.span: Angel confesses to having an affair in London
Angel confesses to having an affair in London, but immediately regretted it and never repeated the offense.

9.text: Angel confesses to having an affair in London, but immediately regretted it and never repeated the offense. Tess then confesses to having an affair with Alec d'Urberville, and Angel seems shocked by the news. Angel says he cannot divorce her because it would cause a scandal, but he also cannot live with her while her former husband is still alive. Tess decides to leave the next day.

10.text: Angel decides to move to Brazil to start a new life there. He informs his parents of his decision and explains that Tess is staying at her mother's house.

errors.span: A year has passed since Clare married Tess

11.text: A year has passed since Clare married Tess, and Tess is still working on the farm, despite her employer's inappropriate behavior towards her. She hears two men talking about Angel's marriage, and how it has estranged him from them.

12.text: Alec, Tess's former seducer, explains that he has changed his ways and now plans to devote his life to missionary work in Africa. He still loves Tess but respects her decision to stay with Angel.

13.text: D'Urberville visits Tess secretly and offers to help her and her family, saying he wants to repay her for the past. Tess hesitates to trust him, but eventually accepts his offer.

errors.span: Angel returns to England after a long absence.

14.text: Angel returns to England after a long absence. He learns that Tess has not used her real name during their separation and that she has undergone hardships rather than ask his father for more funds.

errors.span: Tess must have killed a man

15.text: Angel realizes that Tess must have killed a man, but believes her actions were the result of temporary insanity brought on by grief. They spend several days together in a house before continuing their journey northward. As they walk, Tess says she no longer wishes to live in a world where Angel despises her.

errors.span: If you wish to impose a law of staying and departing on her whom you have chosen for your mistress, you are acting wrongfully

0.text: Who wrought my studious numbers once in happier days now perforce in tears and sadness. Lo, the Muses guide my pen and voice my woe. Down their cheeks unfeigned the tear drops flow to my sad complainings. These alone in danger's hour have dared attend on the footsteps of the exile to his lonely journey's end. Old? Ah yes, swift, ere I knew it, by these sorrows on me pressed age hath come. Death passes by the wretched, but She appeared to be of our age and time. First, will you suffer me to test your mind so that I may learn how to set about your cure? She says: This world of ours, do you think it is governed haphazardly or is there any rational guidance? I say no, in no way may I deem that such fixed motions can be determined by random hazard. If you wish to impose a law of staying and departing on her whom you have chosen for your mistress, you are acting wrongfully.

0.text: Aegon, a merchant of Syracusa, is brought before the Duke and his officers for violating the Duke's laws. The Duke explains that since the mortal and intestine jars between Aegon's countrymen and the Duke's have been decreed, both by the Syracusians and themselves, to admit no traffic to their towns. If Aegon is seen at any of the Syracusian marts or fairs, he dies. Aegon and his wife sail to Epidamnum, but before long, they fear death. Aegon's youngest son becomes inquisitive after his brother and asks his father to take him with him in the quest of his brother. 0.text: Mrs. Touchett returns to her husband's house after many months away. She intends to go to America to look after her investments and her nieces.

errors.span: Isabel, one of the three sisters, is considered the most intelligent of the three.

1.text: Isabel, one of the three sisters, is considered the most intelligent of the three. Caspar Goodwood, a straight young man from Boston, has been interested in Isabel for some time.

2.text: Lord Warburton spends two nights at the estate and spends a lot of time speaking to Isabel. She finds herself liking him very much. He eventually proposes marriage to her, and she says she needs time to think about his offer.

3.text: Isabel tells her uncle she does not wish to marry Lord Warburton. She feels she is not as attracted to him as she is to Caspar.

4.text: Caspar visits Isabel in her hotel room and asks why she didn't reply to his letter. She says she didn't reply because she thought it was the best thing to do. She tells him she cannot marry him as she does not wish to give up on other chances. Caspar says he will wait for two years for her to change her mind.

5.text: Mr. Touchett grows weaker by the day, and tells Ralph he wants him to marry his daughter Isabel after his death. He agrees to divide his inheritance into two halves, one for Isabel.

6.text: During Mr. Touchett's illness, Isabel becomes close to Madame Merle, who is cultured and talented. Mrs. Touchett decides to spend the winter in Paris, where she will formally introduce Isabel to her fellow countrymen.

7.text: Edward Rosier, a young man from New York, takes a great interest in Isabel.

8.text: Isabel inherits a large sum of money from her late uncle. She is afraid of having a large fortune, as it means freedom and she is afraid of not making good use of it.

9.text: Madame Merle introduces Isabel to Gilbert Osmond, an American who has lived in Italy for 30 years. Isabel finds him intriguing. Osmond spends a lot of time with Isabel and her companions, and they all find him to be a pleasant man. He eventually confesses his love for Isabel, but says he has nothing to offer her as he has no fortune or fame. Isabel is surprised by his declaration of love but isn't offended by it.

10.text: Isabel returns to Florence after several months. Her sister, Mrs. Ludlow, has come to stay with her for five months with her two children.

errors.span: living in Rome for a day

antecedants: who has lived in Italy for 30 years
for 30 years

errors.span: Isabel tells her aunt about her engagement to Gilbert Osmond, who is an American living in Rome for a day.

11.text: Isabel tells her aunt about her engagement to Gilbert Osmond, who is an American living in Rome for a day. Her family disapproves of the marriage due to the difference in their financial status.

12.text: Edward Rosier, an American who has spent several winters in Paris, becomes attracted to Pansy Osmond, a young girl he met in the Upper Engadine. He hopes to pursue a relationship with her, but Osmond is determined to prevent their relationship from progressing.

13.text: Madame Merle informs Isabel that she's decided to wash her hands of the love affair between Pansy and Edward, as she doesn't think him to be a good husband for Pansy. Isabel agrees that it would be better for Pansy to marry Lord Warburton than Edward.

14.text: Isabel reflects on the fact that she still feels the same way about Lord Warburton as she once did, but wonders if he still has the same feelings for her. She eventually decides that Lord Warburton is as disinterested in her as she needs him to be.

antecedants: Isabel reflects on

15.text: Isabel reflects on how her distrust of Osmond has developed over time. She initially tried to be who he wanted her to be, but realized she couldn't change who she was.

16.text: The Countess tells Henrietta that Lord Warburton is making advances towards Isabel, and that she is safe. Isabel knows her husband is displeased by Ralph's visit to Rome, but still goes to see him.

errors.span: Ralph tells Goodwood that he doesn't need his help in England, as Henrietta will be able to take care of him.

17.text: Ralph tells Goodwood that he doesn't need his help in England, as Henrietta will be able to take care of him.

18.text: Ralph tells Isabel that he's dying, and she feels conflicted about seeing him again.

19.text: Goodwood asks Isabel what she's made of her life, and says that he loves her and believes he'll never see her again.

20.text: Madame Merle reveals to Isabel that Osmond's first wife was not Pansy's biological mother, and that he had to cover up the truth by saying she died in childbirth. Isabel is shocked by the news.

21.text: Isabel arrives at Gardencourt, where she meets her aunt, Mrs. Touchett. Mrs. Touchett informs her that Ralph can speak to her, and that his life has not been a successful one.

errors.span: her husband married her only for her money.

22.text: Ralph regains consciousness and tells Isabel that he ruined her and that her husband married her only for her money.

23.text: Goodwood tells Isabel that he wants to save her from going back to her husband, and kisses her forcefully.

errors.span: she left for Rome early that morning

24.text: Two days later, Goodwood arrives at Henrietta Stackpole's house in Wimpole Street, looking for Isabel, but is disappointed to learn that she left for Rome early that morning.

0.text: Since Aramis's transformation into a confessor of the order, Baisemeaux no longer feels the same about him. Up to that period, he held Aramis in high esteem as a prelate and a friend, but now he feels inferior and Aramis is his master. Aramis approaches the prisoner's chamber and asks him why he desires a confessor. The prisoner says he is afraid of death and suspects that his enemies have assassinated his nurse and preceptor. Aramis says that the king, if he desires it, can be the one who, quitting his dungeon, shall maintain himself upon the throne. Aramis is the first to descend from the carriage and holds the door open for the prince. Fouquet gazes upon the portrait of the king.

0.text: The philosopher examines the proposition that justice is useful to society and that public utility is the sole origin of its merit. He believes that the rules of justice depend on the particular state and condition in which men are placed.

1.text: It is impossible to believe that nature would instruct us in all the methods of acquiring property without relying on reason.

2.text: Philosophers have assumed that all our concern for the public can be resolved into a concern for our own happiness and preservation, but there are instances in which private interest is separate from public interest.

3.text: Humanity influences our actions and sentiments, and utility is a source of praise and approbation in all moral decisions. Few men would envy the character that Caesar describes of Cassius.

4.text: Men who do not enjoy pleasure are dangerous and cannot contribute to social entertainment. A certain degree of pride is necessary to be pleasing in society.

5.text: The talent of poets to move the passions is a considerable merit that can elevate the person possessing it above all others.

6.text: Good manners are pleasing to others, independent of utility or beneficial tendencies.

7.text: The author argues that personal merit consists of mental qualities that are either useful or agreeable to oneself or to others.

8.text: It is difficult to say which quality is more important to happiness: a friendly heart or extensive genius and courage. Regardless, it is clear that a man's figure in life and the esteem he is held in by others depend on his personal merit.

9.text: Modern philosophers have often followed a different course in their moral enquiries than the ancients. It is important to examine our duty to ourselves in order to see if it bears any resemblance to the duty we owe to society.
